projects.brief: Celebrate the achievements of our very own Teams MVP Zach Bennett
projects.documentContent:
# Celebrating Zach Bennett: Our Very Own Microsoft Teams MVP

We're absolutely thrilled to shine a spotlight on someone who's been making serious waves in the Microsoft Teams community ‚Äî our Principal Architect, Zach Bennett.

Zach has just been renewed as a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional in Microsoft Teams ‚Äî and let's be clear about what that means. Out of the millions of IT professionals working with Microsoft technologies across the United Kingdom, only 18 hold this title for Teams. Eighteen. Microsoft hand-picks these people because they're not just good at what they do ‚Äî they're among the absolute best in the world, actively shaping the future of how enterprises communicate. Zach is one of them.

## From Cisco to Cloud Telephony Champion

Zach's journey is one of those brilliant "follow your passion" stories. He studied Computer Science at Manchester Metropolitan University, and during his placement year at General Electric, he had a realisation that would shape his career: the big corporate life wasn't for him. He wanted somewhere more intimate, where he could wear many hats and really make an impact.

That Computer Science foundation matters. It‚Äôs the kind of degree that forces you to think in systems: how complex parts connect, where failures actually come from, and how to troubleshoot methodically when the obvious answer isn‚Äôt the right one. Pair that with a real industry placement inside a huge organisation, and you get an engineer who can speak both languages ‚Äî the technical detail _and_ the messy reality of how big enterprises operate.

It also explains a lot about Zach today: he‚Äôs not just ‚Äúgood with Teams.‚Äù He‚Äôs good at the underlying problem‚Äîdesigning, debugging, and scaling real-world communications systems that have to work for thousands of people, across multiple countries, under real constraints.

He started out managing Cisco phone systems, but quickly found his true calling in the Microsoft ecosystem ‚Äî first with development work, then Skype for Business, and eventually discovering his passion in voice deployments. As he puts it: "The telephone totally revolutionized the way we could communicate‚Ä¶ What's next?" That forward-thinking mindset has driven everything since.

## What Zach Actually Does (It's a Lot)

As Principal Architect at LoopUp, Zach sits at the heart of our most complex global telephony deployments. This isn't just "set up some phones" work ‚Äî it's enterprise-scale transformation for multinational organisations operating across 100+ countries.

Day to day, Zach leads the full journey: strategic planning, proof-of-concept design, and multi-site rollouts that can span dozens of countries simultaneously. He works directly with global enterprises to migrate them away from fragmented legacy PBX systems ‚Äî often a patchwork of regional carriers, each with their own contracts, billing, support teams, and headaches ‚Äî onto a unified Microsoft Teams Phone platform.

He advises on Microsoft licensing optimisation, security configurations, and modern workplace capabilities, ensuring clients don't just get Teams Phone working, but get the absolute maximum value from it. Whether it's navigating the complexities of Operator Connect, architecting Direct Routing solutions via our Cloud Telephony Platform, or helping organisations tackle tricky markets like China and India, Zach's the one making it happen.

In short: when a Fortune 500 company needs to consolidate their global voice infrastructure and actually make it work seamlessly, Zach's the architect they turn to.

## Building for the Community

What really sets Zach apart is how much he gives back. He doesn't just solve problems for clients ‚Äî he shares what he learns with everyone.

His blog at zachb.uk has become a trusted resource for Teams admins everywhere, covering everything from whether Teams Premium is worth the investment to Voice Isolation features, the new Queues App capabilities, and the latest Direct Routing troubleshooting tools rolling out in Teams Admin Center.

His YouTube channel walks viewers through practical guides on Call Queues, Auto Attendants, and more. And then there's **teamstts.com** ‚Äî a tool Zach built entirely for the community. It lets you test what Text-to-Speech will actually sound like in your Auto Attendants and Call Queues before you go live, using the same voices Microsoft Teams uses on the backend. If you've ever had a company name that TTS absolutely butchers, you'll understand why this is such a lifesaver.

## On Stage and Around the World

Zach's passion for teaching extends well beyond the screen. One of his most memorable career moments came at Comms vNext 2024 in Denver, Colorado ‚Äî his first major international speaking engagement ‚Äî where he presented "Is Teams Ready To Be Your Contact Center?" to an audience of Microsoft communications professionals from around the globe.

Since then, he's become a regular on the conference circuit. Just last November, he was at Microsoft Ignite 2025 in San Francisco, co-presenting "Unlock MS Teams Phone Globally: Insights from World's Leading Brands" with our own Andrew Birch. He's a fixture at Commsverse (the UK's premier Microsoft Teams conference) and is already confirmed to speak at Commsverse 2026.

He's also been featured across industry publications ‚Äî Authority Magazine, AI TechPark, NODE Magazine ‚Äî sharing his insights on the future of enterprise communications and AI-driven telephony.

## The Person Behind the Professional

Here's something you might not know about Zach: his favourite quote is "The Dude abides" from The Big Lebowski. As he explains it, it's about accepting life's challenges, taking things in your stride, and remembering what truly matters. Pretty solid life philosophy, if you ask us.

He's also quick to credit others for his success ‚Äî particularly Graham Cropley, our Head of Global Consulting, who Zach describes as a constant source of knowledge and encouragement throughout his career. And on the personal front, 2025 has been extra special: Zach recently welcomed a baby girl into the world.

## What's Next?

With Teams Phone continuing to evolve at a rapid pace ‚Äî AI-powered features, Copilot integration, new admin tools, enhanced call handling ‚Äî there's never been a more exciting time to be working in this space. And we couldn't be prouder to have Zach leading the charge, both for our clients and for the wider community.

So here's to Zach: MVP, architect, educator, tool builder, new dad, and all-around Teams Phone enthusiast. Congratulations on another well-deserved year of recognition!

---

_Want to follow Zach's work? Check out his blog at [zachb.uk](https://www.zachb.uk), his [YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/)._

Title: UI Improvements coming to Teams Phone - LinkedIn
Published Date: 2024-05-29T00:00:00.000Z
URL: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/ui-improvements-coming-teams-phone-zach-bennett-ijzne
Text: UI Improvements coming to Teams Phone

Enterprise Connect 2024 also [announced] some Teams Phone device UI improvements! These are quality of life improvements that I believe will greatly increase the useability of Teams Phone on devices.

A quick overview of these upcoming UI improvements are:

- Advanced contact management ‚Äì add external number contacts for quick dialling
- Simpler multi-call handling - configure how incoming calls will be routed when on an ongoing call or meeting
- New call handling capabilities ‚Äì Call Forwarding from home screen, send incoming calls to voicemail, call of behalf of queue, quicker call transfers

Image showing the upcoming features from the Enterprise Connect announcement

These features have been mentioned they will be made available next quarter 2024. However, we already have seen some of these features show up on the roadmap which is great to see!

- Enabling call forwarding directly from phone device home screen ‚Äì Roadmap [388490] 
- Redirect incoming call direct to voicemail ‚Äì Roadmap [169887] 

##

This feature will allow users to send and receive SMS messages natively in their Teams client. Importantly, this is via Windows Desktop, Teams for Mac Desktop, and Teams for iOS and Android. This is great because we are seeing features released across many ways people use Teams at the same time.

This feature currently has the following requirements:

- Calling Plans
- United States and Canada

input.content:
# Celebrating Zach Bennett: Our Very Own Microsoft Teams MVP

We're absolutely thrilled to shine a spotlight on someone who's been making serious waves in the Microsoft Teams community ‚Äî our Principal Architect, Zach Bennett.

For those who don't know, Zach was recently renewed as a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional (MVP) in Microsoft Teams. That's not just a fancy title ‚Äî it's recognition from Microsoft themselves that Zach is one of the go-to voices helping shape how organisations around the world use Teams Phone.

## From Cisco to Cloud Telephony Champion

Zach's journey into the world of voice technology started with managing Cisco phone systems, but he quickly found his true calling (pun intended) in the Microsoft ecosystem. With over a decade of hands-on experience in unified communications, he's become the person global enterprises turn to when they need to migrate from clunky, outdated PBX systems to modern Microsoft Teams Phone deployments.

Here at LoopUp, Zach leads some of our most complex global telephony projects ‚Äî working with multinational organisations to roll out Teams Phone across dozens of countries. It's the kind of work that requires deep technical expertise, but also the ability to see the bigger picture and help clients navigate the real-world challenges of going global with their communications.

## Building for the Community

What really sets Zach apart is how much he gives back. He doesn't just solve problems for clients ‚Äî he shares what he learns with everyone.

His blog at zachb.uk has become a trusted resource for Teams admins everywhere, covering everything from whether Teams Premium is worth the investment to the latest features rolling out in Teams Admin Center. His YouTube channel walks viewers through practical guides on Call Queues, Auto Attendants, and more.

And then there's teamstts.com ‚Äî a tool Zach built entirely for the community. It lets you test what Text-to-Speech will actually sound like in your Auto Attendants and Call Queues before you go live. If you've ever had a client name that TTS absolutely butchers, you'll understand why this is such a lifesaver.

## On Stage and On the Road

Zach's passion for teaching extends beyond the screen. He's a regular speaker at industry conferences like Commsverse and Comms vNext, and just last November he was representing LoopUp at Microsoft Ignite 2025 in San Francisco. He's been featured in AI TechPark, Authority Magazine, and various industry spotlights discussing the future of enterprise telephony.

## What's Next?

With Teams Phone continuing to evolve at a rapid pace ‚Äî SMS integration, new admin tools, enhanced call handling ‚Äî there's never been a more exciting time to be working in this space. And we couldn't be prouder to have Zach leading the charge.

So here's to Zach: MVP, architect, educator, tool builder, and all-around Teams Phone enthusiast. Congratulations on another well-deserved year of recognition!

---

*Want to follow Zach's work? Check out his blog at zachb.uk or connect with him on LinkedIn.*

Future of Voice Applications Policies

Voice Applications Policies are a way for administrators to delegate Auto Attendant and Call Queue changes to specific authorized users in their organisation.

Currently, you are able to allow these authorized users to change the following settings:

- Auto Attendants
 - Business Hour greeting
 - After Hour greeting
 - Holiday greeting
- Call Queues
 - Welcome Greeting
 - Music on Hold
 - Shared Voicemail greeting for call overflow
 - Shared Voicemail greeting for call timeout
 - Shared Voicemail greeting for no agents

Rolling out in [March 2025] is a brand-new feature to the Teams Admin Center that I think will be super useful to admins of their Microsoft Teams Phone deployment. This is the ability to review SIP Ladder diagrams directly in the Teams Admin Center.

These reports will be available under the Usage Reports pages section of the Teams Admin Center and allow admins to view SIP requests, responses, and SDP data between the Microsoft Teams proxy and SBC the call was routed through.

These calls will be made available on these reports no earlier than 30 minutes after the call was made and be stored for 30 days.

# AITech Interview with Zach Bennett, Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp

by [AI TechPark](https://ai-techpark.com/author/techpark/)September 23, 2025October 17, 2025

![AITech Interview with Zach Bennett, Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp](https://ai-techpark.com/wp-content/uploads/Ai-interview-format-4.jpg)

***AI-driven cloud telephony elevates productivity and workflow precision in modern enterprise communication.***

**Zach, as a Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp, could you share how your journey has evolved within the world of Microsoft technologies and voice technologies, and how it led you to your current role?**

I started my career managing and supporting Cisco phone systems. Since making the move into the Microsoft technology stack, I‚Äôve seen constant enhancements and innovations whilst supporting, managing, consulting, and architecting against the industry leader in voice technologies and UC platforms. This has led me into a role that I love where I can help truly global organizations migrate from their aging Phone Systems to Microsoft Teams Phone. It has driven me to help the wider voice community and as a result for my contributions I was awarded by Microsoft who invited me to join their Microsoft Most Valuable Professionals group of leaders.

**AI is increasingly transforming industries, including telecommunications. In your view, how is AI currently impacting the telecommunications sector, particularly with regard to cloud-based communication systems like Microsoft Teams?**

Voice can often be forgotten in this world of fast-moving technology. However, AI is so wide reaching that customers are looking for what sort of AI functionality they‚Äôll be able to utilize in their Phone Systems right now. Cloud-based communication systems like Microsoft Teams are front runners in this aspect as they offer some AI capabilities already as part of their Copilot M365 offering.

The integration of telecom call data into enterprise datasets is crucial for AI analysis. What are the implications for enterprises if they fail to include telecom data, and how does this impact the value of AI within those organizations?

AI becomes invaluable if you‚Äôre an organization that is doing everything right including valuing your data collection and capturing emails, meetings and CRM data, but are missing out on call data. Without that call data, you‚Äôre not providing the full picture to your AI service because you‚Äôre missing out on a core communication stream of data for your company. This can cause inaccuracies in your data and skew trends.

**Given your experience with transitioning organizations from traditional PBX systems to Microsoft Teams Phone, how do you think AI can enhance productivity when implemented correctly within these platforms?**

If you‚Äôre using a Phone System and provider that can allow you to utilize AI in the correct way, it can allow your user‚Äôs experience of the Phone System to be greatly enhanced. For example, when taking calls, being able to summarize the call before transferring that onto another colleague gives them the information they need to act effectively and efficiently on the call. Also, providing real-time transcriptions that users can refer back to and integrate through the [AI agent](https://ai-techpark.com/ai-agents-vs-ai-assistants-key-differences/) on the call can massively increase productivity.

**With the growing role of AI in enterprise environments, what are the key challenges businesses face when integrating telecom data with AI technologies, and how can they overcome these hurdles?**

I believe the challenges of integrating telecom data with AI will be very similar to challenges that we‚Äôve already seen with AI. These challenges ‚Äî such as security and compliance ‚Äî can be seen as sensitive information for telecom data. It is important to make sure you have adopted advanced security measures such as encryption and regular audits so that you are compliant with regulations. Scalability is another challenge as telecom data can be fast, complex, and big, so making sure your AI system can handle this increase of data is key.

**As cloud-based telephony and AI converge, how do you envision the future of communication systems in large enterprises, and what role will platforms like Microsoft Teams play in shaping this future?**

[Cloud-based telephony such as Microsoft Teams are already shaping the future of how AI works with your phone system by innovating and offering AI features directly in Microsoft Teams Phone.](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Cloud-based%20telephony%20such%20as%20Microsoft%20Teams%20are%20already%20shaping%20the%20future%20of%20how%20AI%20works%20with%20your%20phone%20system%20by%20innovating%20and%20offering%20AI%20features%20directly%20in%20Microsoft%20Teams%20Phone.) Its seamless integration with other Microsoft 365 tolls and services enables a truly unified communication experience.

I envision the future of communication will be about creating seamless, intelligent interactions that enhance both employee productivity and customer experience. [AI-powered](https://ai-techpark.com/ai-powered-mental-health-workplace-strategies/) communication hubs, context-aware messaging systems, and automated workflow integration are some of the innovations that will drive this transformation. Microsoft Teams is at the forefront of this evolution, offering features such as AI-driven automation, real-time speech analytics and AI Agent driven contact centers.

**AI has the potential to enhance communication workflows. How can enterprises ensure they‚Äôre getting the most productivity benefits from AI while also maintaining a high level of security and compliance in their communication systems?**

***Choosing an AI service that has deep integration with the rest of your technology stack and that you trust would be a good place to start.*** Something like Copilot for example, if you‚Äôre using Microsoft Teams Phone, is good for seamless integration. You should ensure that training and awareness has been covered for your users to confirm they are aware of security and compliance implications when using AI. It is also important to provide them with the correct education around this so they‚Äôre safe and not unintentionally breaking compliance.

**What role do telecom providers like LoopUp play in ensuring seamless AI integration for businesses using Microsoft Teams, and how does this impact the overall performance of communication systems?**

Telecom providers like LoopUp play a big role in making sure customers are correctly informed about the benefits of AI and how to use them safely within their organizations. We take a consultative approach when it comes to newer technologies like this and inform customers of best practices and how they can enhance their current communication workflows and achieve more out of their communication systems.

**Many organizations are still operating on outdated PBX systems. What are the most significant advantages of transitioning to cloud-based systems like Microsoft Teams Phone with the addition of AI-enhanced capabilities?**

There are so many to choose from but here are 3 that resonate a lot when I‚Äôm talking to customers:

‚óè Take advantage of advanced calling features ‚Äì Microsoft Teams offers many advanced calling features which can enhance how you currently use your phone system and gives users massive productivity boosts.  
‚óè Cost Savings ‚Äì Cloud based systems eliminate the need for expensive on-premises hardware and reduce ongoing management and maintenance costs.  
‚óè Scalability and futureproofing ‚Äì Making sure that your phone system is also able to grow with you as a business, and having the ability and flexibility to add or remove additional users without the need to invest in new infrastructure.

**What are some of the most exciting developments you foresee in AI and telecommunications, and how can businesses start preparing for these innovations to stay ahead in the competitive landscape?**

AI is only going to grow when it comes to the telecommunications features we‚Äôve already mentioned such as real-time transcription, summarization, and AI agents ‚Äî these are only the start. As companies like Microsoft see the increased adoption of Copilot against Microsoft Teams Phone, new functionalities will start to be released that will enhance user productivity, streamline workflows and incentivize customers to try out these features. If you haven‚Äôt already, look to modernize your phone system and move it to the Cloud to give your business these advantages that will make you well placed to embrace these AI features.

## **Zach Bennett**

Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp

-   [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/)

Currently, I am a Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp, a leading Cloud Telephony provider. At LoopUp, we specialize in offering PSTN solutions built around Microsoft Teams and are proud participants in the Operator Connect program. In my day-to-day role, I work closely with global organizations, assisting them in transitioning from their outdated PBX systems to Microsoft Teams Phone. Leveraging Operator Connect or Direct Routing via the LoopUp Cloud Telephony Platform, I help these organizations seamlessly migrate and unlock the full potential of Microsoft Teams for their communication needs.

# **Zach Bennett Of LoopUp On The Future Of Communication Technology**

[

![David Leichner](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fill:64:64/1*qwGbkAf57Rk-SVw-Yk6-IQ.jpeg)





](/@davidleichner?source=post_page---byline--1bbf73e9ed43---------------------------------------)

[David Leichner](/@davidleichner?source=post_page---byline--1bbf73e9ed43---------------------------------------)

8 min read

¬∑

May 20, 2025

[

](/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fvote%2Fauthority-magazine%2F1bbf73e9ed43&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fauthority-magazine%2Fzach-bennett-of-loopup-on-the-future-of-communication-technology-1bbf73e9ed43&user=David+Leichner&userId=673c6139d301&source=---header_actions--1bbf73e9ed43---------------------clap_footer------------------)

\--

[](/m/signin?actionUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2F_%2Fbookmark%2Fp%2F1bbf73e9ed43&operation=register&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fmedium.com%2Fauthority-magazine%2Fzach-bennett-of-loopup-on-the-future-of-communication-technology-1bbf73e9ed43&source=---header_actions--1bbf73e9ed43---------------------bookmark_footer------------------)

Listen

Share

Press enter or click to view image in full size

> **Embrace Continuous Learning**: Tech evolves rapidly, and staying updated with the latest trends and technologies is crucial. Embracing a mindset of continuous learning will help you stay relevant and grow in your career.

T*he telephone totally revolutionized the way we could communicate with people all over the world. But then came email and took it to the next level. And then came text messaging. And then came video calls. And so on‚Ä¶What‚Äôs next? What‚Äôs just around the corner?*

*In this interview series, called ‚ÄòThe Future Of Communication Technology‚Äô we are interviewing leaders of tech or telecom companies who are helping to develop emerging communication technologies and the next generation of how we communicate and connect with each other.*

*As a part of this series, I had the pleasure of interviewing Zach Bennett, Principal Architect at LoopUp.*

*Zach Bennett has been immersed in the world of Microsoft technologies since graduating from university 9 years ago, where he had a special focus on voice technologies. Throughout his career, Zach has found joy in sharing his expertise and knowledge with others. Teaching has always been a passion of his, and he is eager to expand his reach and connect with a broader technical community through engaging talks and presentations.*

*Currently, Zach is a Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp, a leading Cloud Telephony provider. At LoopUp, the company specializes in offering PSTN solutions built around Microsoft Teams and is proud to participate in the Operator Connect program. In his day-to-day role, Zach works closely with global organizations, assisting them in transitioning from their outdated PBX systems to Microsoft Teams Phone. Leveraging Operator Connect or Direct Routing via the LoopUp Cloud Telephony Platform, he helps these organizations seamlessly migrate and unlock the full potential of Microsoft Teams for their communication needs.*

**Thank you so much for joining us in this interview series! Before we dive in, our readers would love to ‚Äúget to know you‚Äù a bit better. Can you tell us a bit about your ‚Äòbackstory‚Äô and how you got started?**

I studied Computer Science at Manchester Metropolitan University, and during my year in industry at General Electric, I realized that the big company life might not be for me. I wanted a workplace that was more intimate, where I could wear many hats and help out wherever possible.

My interest in Microsoft technologies led me to development work, and eventually, I found my passion in voice deployments with Skype for Business and Microsoft Teams. This is where I discovered what I truly love to do, and I‚Äôve been pursuing it ever since.

The announcement and success of Microsoft Teams opened up a whole new dimension to my career. I delved into the telephony side of Teams, and I enjoyed sharing my knowledge with the community through technical blogs, videos, and speaking engagements. This journey led me to LoopUp, where we have a revolutionary approach to Microsoft Teams calling and the technology behind it, which I now help deliver to our customers. Along with this, my continued commitment to community work has offered me the opportunity to join the Microsoft MVP program specialising in Microsoft Teams where I am 1/18 in the UK.

**Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you began your career?**

One of the most interesting and memorable experiences in my career happened when I was invited to talk at CommsVNext in Denver, CO. As a Microsoft Teams MVP, I had the opportunity to present at this prestigious international event, which is dedicated to Microsoft Communications and Collaborations Technologies.

The event was held at the hotel in downtown Denver, and it was an incredible experience from start to finish. I remember preparing extensively for my presentation called ‚ÄúIs Teams ready to be your Contact Center?‚Äù where I explored the capabilities of Microsoft Teams in handling complex communication needs and shared insights on maximizing its effectiveness.

What made this experience truly special was the sense of community and the opportunity to connect with like-minded professionals. The event was well-organized, with all sessions, exhibitors, and food in close proximity, making it easy to engage with attendees and participate in various discussions.

During my talk, I shared real-world customer scenarios and solutions, which resonated well with the audience. The feedback I received was overwhelmingly positive, and it was gratifying to see how my insights could help others in their journey with Microsoft Teams.

Overall, CommsVNext in Denver was an unforgettable experience that reinforced my passion for Microsoft technologies and the importance of community engagement. It was a privilege to be part of such a vibrant and knowledgeable group of professionals, and I look forward to future opportunities to share and learn at similar events.

**Can you please give us your favorite ‚ÄúLife Lesson Quote‚Äù? Can you share how that was relevant to you in your life?**

‚ÄúThe Dude abides‚Äù The Dude ‚Äî The Big Lebowski

This quote is from my favorite film, The Big Lebowski. It can mean a lot of things to a lot of people, and to me it reflects the acceptance of life‚Äôs challenges. In the book, ‚ÄúThe Dude and the Zen Master‚Äù, they talk about Zen principles and how the Dude reflects these throughout the movie and how you can throughout your life. It‚Äôs a simple quote that helps me remember whatever is going on through your personal or work life you can survive. Take it in your stride, remember what matters, and also, ‚ÄúThe Dude abides‚Äù.

**None of us are able to achieve success without some help along the way. Is there a particular person who you are grateful towards who helped get you to where you are? Can you share a story about that?**

For me that person would be my current colleague and Head of Global Consulting at LoopUp, [Graham Cropley](https://www.linkedin.com/in/grahamcropley/). He is someone I‚Äôve had the pleasure of working with throughout my career across multiple businesses and has allowed me to flourish as a consultant. Graham has been a constant source of knowledge and encouragement towards hitting my career goals.

A story that comes to mind is when Graham and I were working together before LoopUp there was a security workshop that needed to be completed by a couple of consultants, and he thought of me as I‚Äôd shown interest. We met up the night before the presentation and I was freaking out as it was my first presentation in front of such a big customer and I didn‚Äôt feel like I knew the material well enough. We spent time going through the deck and he said to me ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know this either, let‚Äôs work it out‚Äù. You don‚Äôt have to know everything all the time, but if you‚Äôre willing to spend the effort to work it out it goes a long way.

**How have you used your success to bring goodness to the world?**

As a Microsoft Teams MVP, I‚Äôve dedicated a significant amount of time to sharing my expertise with the community. Through technical blogs, videos, and speaking engagements, I‚Äôve helped others understand and leverage Microsoft Teams and other technologies to improve their workflows and communication.

**Ok wonderful. Let‚Äôs now shift to the main focus of our interview. Can you tell us about the cutting-edge communication tech that you are working on? How do you think that will help people?**

Our cloud telephony solution at [LoopUp](https://loopup.com/us/) aims to transform Microsoft Teams from an internal collaboration tool into a fully-fledged unified communications platform. This allows users to make and receive external phone calls from any Teams-enabled device, providing a seamless and integrated communication experience.

**How do you think this might change the world?**

By enabling PSTN calling through Microsoft Teams, users can stay connected from anywhere, whether they‚Äôre in the office, working from home, or on the go. This flexibility is crucial in today‚Äôs hybrid work environment.

**Keeping ‚Äú**[**Black Mirror**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_Mirror)**‚Äù in mind, can you see any potential drawbacks about this technology that people should think more deeply about?**

With Black Mirror in mind, having constant contact available via mobile devices and Microsoft Teams could potentially blur the boundaries between work and personal life. It‚Äôs important to make sure there is enough education out there about having a healthy work-life balance.

**Was there a ‚Äútipping point‚Äù that led you to this breakthrough? Can you tell us that story?**

I saw the immense potential of integrating telephony with Teams and it motivated me to pursue this path, join LoopUp and share my knowledge with the community through technical blogs, videos, and speaking engagements. This journey has been incredibly rewarding, and I‚Äôm excited to continue exploring new possibilities in communication technology.

**What do you need to lead this technology to widespread adoption?**

Widespread adoption of Microsoft Teams is already prevalent in my opinion, however, to stay ahead of the competition there still needs to be a steady stream of feature updates that will make Teams telephony more usable across different organizations. At LoopUp we also can increase this widespread adoption due to our increased global coverage of 66 countries and cost-saving capabilities which will make these technologies more accessible.

**The pandemic has changed so many things about the way we behave. One of them of course is how we work and how we communicate in our work. How do you think your innovation might be able to address the new needs that have arisen as a result of the pandemic?**

Our solution enables PSTN calling through Microsoft Teams, allowing users to stay connected from anywhere, whether they‚Äôre in the office, working from home, or on the go. This flexibility is crucial in today‚Äôs hybrid work environment where employees need to be able to communicate seamlessly regardless of their location. Along with this, moving to a cloud-based telephony system can significantly reduce costs associated with maintaining traditional phone systems. It also offers scalability, allowing businesses to easily adjust their communication infrastructure as they grow. This is particularly important in the post-pandemic world, where many organizations are looking to optimize their operations and reduce expenses.

Press enter or click to view image in full size

**What are your ‚Äú5 Things I Wish Someone Told Me Before I Started‚Äù and why?**

1.  **Embrace Continuous Learning**: Tech evolves rapidly, and staying updated with the latest trends and technologies is crucial. Embracing a mindset of continuous learning will help you stay relevant and grow in your career.
2.  **Networking is Key**: Building a strong professional network can open up many opportunities. Attend industry events, join online communities, and connect with peers. These relationships can provide support, advice, and potential career advancements.
3.  **Don‚Äôt Fear Failure**: Failure is a part of the learning process. Each setback is an opportunity to learn and improve.
4.  **Work-Life Balance Matters**: It‚Äôs easy to get consumed by work, especially in a fast-paced industry. Prioritize your well-being and maintain a healthy work-life balance. This will help you stay productive and avoid burnout.
5.  **Soft Skills are Essential**: Technical skills are important, but soft skills like communication, teamwork, and problem-solving are equally valuable. These skills will help you collaborate effectively and advance in your career.

**You are a person of great influence. If you could inspire a movement that would bring the most amount of good to the most amount of people, what would that be? You never know what your idea can trigger. :-)**

One thing that I believe is very important is supporting lifelong learning by providing resources and platforms for continuous learning and skill development. This would help people stay updated with the latest in technological advancements and make you available to adapt to the changing job market and technology solutions.

**How can our readers further follow your work online?**

**LinkedIn** *‚Äî* [https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/)

**YouTube** *‚Äî* [https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett](https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett)

**Thank you so much for the time you spent doing this interview. This was very inspirational, and we wish you continued success.**

# Meet Zach Bennett

## Microsoft Teams MVP ¬†|¬† Principal Architect at LoopUp

[ LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/) [ YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett)

## Background and education

Zach studied Computer Science at Manchester Metropolitan University. During a placement year at General Electric, he realised he preferred a working environment where he could take on diverse responsibilities rather than a conventional large-company structure.

## Professional expertise

Zach has over a decade of experience in Microsoft unified-communications (UC) and voice solutions ‚Äî in particular focusing on telephony and voice integration with collaboration tools. As Principal Architect at LoopUp, he leads global deployments of Microsoft Teams Phone for enterprise clients ‚Äî from strategic planning and proof-of-concept to multi-site rollouts. He advises organisations on optimising Microsoft licensing, security, and modern workplace capabilities to ensure enterprises can fully leverage Teams and cloud-based telephony.

[![Zach Bennett thought leadership](https://loopup.com/app/uploads/2025/12/zach-bennett-thought-leadership.jpg)](https://www.node-magazine.com/thoughtleadership/multinational-businesses-are-struggling-to-breathe-under-the-weight-of-geographically-bound-telephony)

## Thought leadership and community engagement

Zach participates actively in the broader technical community: he writes technical blogs, produces educational content, and delivers talks and presentations on voice deployments and modern communications. He was featured in a 2025 interview discussing the future of communication technology, articulating how cloud telephony and integrated communication platforms can transform enterprise communication.

## Philosophy and approach

Zach balances technical acumen with a consultative mindset ‚Äî he prioritises continuous learning, staying abreast of evolving telecom and UC trends, and helping clients navigate migrations from legacy PBX systems to cloud-native solutions. In his own words (from a public interview): ‚ÄúThe telephone totally revolutionized the way we could communicate ‚Ä¶ What‚Äôs next?‚Äù ‚Äî reflecting his forward-looking view on communication technologies.

> ‚ÄúThe telephone totally revolutionized the way we could communicate ‚Ä¶ What‚Äôs next?‚Äù

## Role at LoopUp and impact

At LoopUp ‚Äî a global cloud-communications provider offering managed telephony around Microsoft Teams and operating across 100+ countries ‚Äî Zach ensures enterprises can modernise voice infrastructure with minimal friction.

His work supports customers in consolidating fragmented telephony systems, reducing cost and complexity, and providing a scalable, secure, and consistent global communication platform.

[Agent Usage Reminder]

You called a search/fetch tool directly without leveraging specialized agents.

RECOMMENDED: Use delegate_task with explore/librarian agents for better results:

```
// Parallel exploration - fire multiple agents simultaneously
delegate_task(agent="explore", prompt="Find all files matching pattern X")
delegate_task(agent="explore", prompt="Search for implementation of Y") 
delegate_task(agent="librarian", prompt="Lookup documentation for Z")

// Then continue your work while they run in background
// System will notify you when each completes
```

WHY:
- Agents can perform deeper, more thorough searches
- Background tasks run in parallel, saving time
- Specialized agents have domain expertise
- Reduces context window usage in main session

ALWAYS prefer: Multiple parallel delegate_task calls > Direct tool calls

I found a LOT more about Zach. Here's the comprehensive summary of additional details:

## Additional Information Found

### Career Journey
- **Education**: Computer Science at Manchester Metropolitan University with a placement year at General Electric
- **Career Path**: Started with Cisco phone systems ‚Üí Microsoft development ‚Üí Skype for Business ‚Üí Microsoft Teams Phone specialist
- **Current Status**: One of only **18 Microsoft Teams MVPs in the UK**
- **Mentor**: Credits Graham Cropley (Head of Global Consulting at LoopUp) for helping him flourish as a consultant

### Speaking Highlights
- **Comms vNext 2024 (Denver, CO)**: His first major international speaking engagement ‚Äî presented "Is Teams Ready To Be Your Contact Center?" ‚Äî described it as one of the most memorable experiences in his career
- **Microsoft Ignite 2025 (San Francisco)**: Co-presented "Unlock MS Teams Phone Globally; Insights from World's Leading Brands" with Andrew Birch
- **Commsverse 2025 & 2026**: Confirmed regular speaker
- **LoopUp Webcasts**: Hosted a 6-part webinar series covering Teams telephony, Operator Connect, Copilot integration, and more

### Media & Publications
- **Authority Magazine** (May 2025): Full feature on "The Future of Communication Technology"
- **AI TechPark** (September 2025): In-depth interview on AI and cloud telephony
- **NODE Magazine** (September 2025): Featured article on global telephony challenges

### Blog Posts (zachb.uk)
Extensive coverage including:
- Is Teams Premium Worth It?
- Direct Routing Troubleshooting tools
- SMS Coming to Microsoft Teams Phone
- Voice Isolation in Microsoft Teams
- Queues App features (Monitor, Whisper, Barge, Takeover)
- Voice Enabled Channels
- Dynamics 365 Contact Center
- Multiple Numbers Assigned to Users
- Blocking Numbers Tenant-Wide

### Personal Touches
- **Favourite Quote**: "The Dude abides" (from The Big Lebowski) ‚Äî he references Zen principles and using it to accept life's challenges
- **Philosophy**: Emphasises continuous learning, work-life balance, networking, not fearing failure, and the importance of soft skills
- **New Dad**: Welcomed a baby girl in early 2025 (announced return from paternity leave in March)

### Community Tools
- **teamstts.com**: Built this tool for the community to test Text-to-Speech for Auto Attendants and Call Queues before deploying ‚Äî uses the same voices Microsoft Teams uses on the backend

Would you like me to update the draft with any of these additional details?

input.content:
# MVP Celebration - Zach Bennett

**Type**: blog
**Word Count**: ~500

## Brief

Celebrate the achievements of Zach Bennett, Microsoft Teams MVP and Principal Architect at LoopUp.

## Key Points to Highlight

### Professional Background
- **Current Role**: Principal Architect at LoopUp, a leading Cloud Telephony provider (operates in 100+ countries)
- **MVP Status**: Microsoft Teams MVP ‚Äî one of only 18 in the UK ‚Äî recently renewed for another year (July 2025)
- **Education**: Computer Science degree from Manchester Metropolitan University
- **Early Career**: Placement year at General Electric; started career managing Cisco phone systems before transitioning to Microsoft technologies
- **Experience**: Over a decade in Microsoft unified communications (UC) and voice solutions
- **Career Evolution**: Moved from Cisco ‚Üí Microsoft development work ‚Üí Skype for Business deployments ‚Üí Microsoft Teams Phone specialist

### Specialisation & Expertise
- Microsoft Teams Phone deployments for global enterprises
- Operator Connect and Direct Routing via LoopUp Cloud Telephony Platform
- Migrating organisations from legacy PBX systems to cloud-based telephony
- Microsoft licensing optimisation, security, and modern workplace capabilities
- Global telephony strategy for multinational enterprises

### Thought Leadership & Community Contributions
- **Personal Blog**: zachb.uk ‚Äî covers Teams Premium, Direct Routing troubleshooting, SMS features, Voice Isolation, Queues App, and more
- **YouTube Channel**: Tutorials on Call Queues, Auto Attendants, and Teams Phone features
- **Community Tool**: Built teamstts.com ‚Äî a free Text-to-Speech tester for Teams Phone Auto Attendants and Call Queues
- **LinkedIn Articles**: Regular technical articles on Teams Phone features, blocking numbers, multiple user numbers, etc.

### Speaking Engagements
- **Comms vNext 2024 (Denver, CO)**: "Is Teams Ready To Be Your Contact Center?" ‚Äî his first major international speaking engagement
- **Commsverse 2025 (UK)**: Regular speaker at the Microsoft Teams Conference
- **Microsoft Ignite 2025 (San Francisco)**: Presented "Unlock MS Teams Phone Globally; Insights from World's Leading Brands" (co-presented with Andrew Birch)
- Confirmed speaker for **Commsverse 2026**

### Media Features & Interviews
- **Authority Magazine** (May 2025): "The Future of Communication Technology"
- **AI TechPark** (September 2025): Interview on AI and cloud telephony
- **NODE Magazine** (September 2025): "Breaking Free from Geographically Bound Telephony"
- **LoopUp Webcasts**: Hosted 6-part webinar series on Teams telephony including episodes on Operator Connect, Copilot integration, and user empowerment

### Personal Philosophy
- Favourite quote: "The Dude abides" (from The Big Lebowski) ‚Äî reflects acceptance of life's challenges
- Values continuous learning, work-life balance, and soft skills alongside technical expertise
- Grateful to mentor Graham Cropley (Head of Global Consulting at LoopUp) for career guidance
- Passionate about teaching and sharing knowledge with the community

### Personal Life
- Recently became a father (baby girl, announced March 2025)
- Based in the UK

## Style Hints

casual, friendly, personal

## Tone

Celebratory, warm, highlighting both professional achievements and community contributions. Show he's relatable ‚Äî someone who went from uni placement to industry-leading MVP through passion and hard work.

input.content:
# Celebrating Zach Bennett: Our Very Own Microsoft Teams MVP

We're absolutely thrilled to shine a spotlight on someone who's been making serious waves in the Microsoft Teams community ‚Äî our Principal Architect, Zach Bennett.

For those who don't know, Zach was recently renewed as a Microsoft Most Valuable Professional (MVP) in Microsoft Teams. And here's the thing ‚Äî he's one of only 18 Teams MVPs in the entire UK. That's not just a fancy title; it's recognition from Microsoft themselves that Zach is one of the go-to voices helping shape how organisations around the world use Teams Phone.

## From Cisco to Cloud Telephony Champion

Zach's journey is one of those brilliant "follow your passion" stories. He studied Computer Science at Manchester Metropolitan University, and during his placement year at General Electric, he had a realisation that would shape his career: the big corporate life wasn't for him. He wanted somewhere more intimate, where he could wear many hats and really make an impact.

He started out managing Cisco phone systems, but quickly found his true calling in the Microsoft ecosystem ‚Äî first with development work, then Skype for Business, and eventually discovering his passion in voice deployments. As he puts it: "The telephone totally revolutionized the way we could communicate‚Ä¶ What's next?" That forward-thinking mindset has driven everything since.

Now, with over a decade of hands-on experience in unified communications, Zach leads some of our most complex global telephony projects here at LoopUp ‚Äî helping multinational organisations across 100+ countries migrate from clunky legacy PBX systems to modern Microsoft Teams Phone.

## Building for the Community

What really sets Zach apart is how much he gives back. He doesn't just solve problems for clients ‚Äî he shares what he learns with everyone.

His blog at zachb.uk has become a trusted resource for Teams admins everywhere, covering everything from whether Teams Premium is worth the investment to Voice Isolation features, the new Queues App capabilities, and the latest Direct Routing troubleshooting tools rolling out in Teams Admin Center.

His YouTube channel walks viewers through practical guides on Call Queues, Auto Attendants, and more. And then there's **teamstts.com** ‚Äî a tool Zach built entirely for the community. It lets you test what Text-to-Speech will actually sound like in your Auto Attendants and Call Queues before you go live, using the same voices Microsoft Teams uses on the backend. If you've ever had a company name that TTS absolutely butchers, you'll understand why this is such a lifesaver.

## On Stage and Around the World

Zach's passion for teaching extends well beyond the screen. One of his most memorable career moments came at Comms vNext 2024 in Denver, Colorado ‚Äî his first major international speaking engagement ‚Äî where he presented "Is Teams Ready To Be Your Contact Center?" to an audience of Microsoft communications professionals from around the globe.

Since then, he's become a regular on the conference circuit. Just last November, he was at Microsoft Ignite 2025 in San Francisco, co-presenting "Unlock MS Teams Phone Globally: Insights from World's Leading Brands" with our own Andrew Birch. He's a fixture at Commsverse (the UK's premier Microsoft Teams conference) and is already confirmed to speak at Commsverse 2026.

He's also been featured across industry publications ‚Äî Authority Magazine, AI TechPark, NODE Magazine ‚Äî sharing his insights on the future of enterprise communications and AI-driven telephony.

## The Person Behind the Professional

Here's something you might not know about Zach: his favourite quote is "The Dude abides" from The Big Lebowski. As he explains it, it's about accepting life's challenges, taking things in your stride, and remembering what truly matters. Pretty solid life philosophy, if you ask us.

He's also quick to credit others for his success ‚Äî particularly Graham Cropley, our Head of Global Consulting, who Zach describes as a constant source of knowledge and encouragement throughout his career. And on the personal front, 2025 has been extra special: Zach recently welcomed a baby girl into the world.

## What's Next?

With Teams Phone continuing to evolve at a rapid pace ‚Äî AI-powered features, Copilot integration, new admin tools, enhanced call handling ‚Äî there's never been a more exciting time to be working in this space. And we couldn't be prouder to have Zach leading the charge, both for our clients and for the wider community.

So here's to Zach: MVP, architect, educator, tool builder, new dad, and all-around Teams Phone enthusiast. Congratulations on another well-deserved year of recognition!

---

*Want to follow Zach's work? Check out his blog at [zachb.uk](https://www.zachb.uk), his [YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/).*

input.newString:

He works directly with global enterprises to migrate them away from fragmented legacy PBX systems ‚Äî often a patchwork of regional carriers, each with their own contracts, billing, support teams, and headaches ‚Äî onto a unified Microsoft Teams Phone platform.

He advises on Microsoft licensing optimisation, security configurations, and modern workplace capabilities, ensuring clients don't just get Teams Phone working, but get the absolute maximum value from it. Whether it's navigating the complexities of Operator Connect, architecting Direct Routing solutions via our Cloud Telephony Platform, or helping organisations tackle tricky markets like China and India, Zach's the one making it happen.

In short: when a Fortune 500 company needs to consolidate their global voice infrastructure and actually make it work seamlessly, Zach's the architect they turn to.

Here's something you might not know about Zach: his favourite quote is "The Dude abides" from The Big Lebowski. As he explains it, it's about accepting life's challenges, taking things in your stride, and remembering what truly matters. Pretty solid life philosophy, if you ask us.

He's also quick to credit others for his success ‚Äî particularly Graham Cropley, our Head of Global Consulting, who Zach describes as a constant source of knowledge and encouragement throughout his career. And on the personal front, 2025 has been extra special: Zach recently welcomed a baby girl into the world.

## What's Next?

With Teams Phone continuing to evolve at a rapid pace ‚Äî AI-powered features, Copilot integration, new admin tools, enhanced call handling ‚Äî there's never been a more exciting time to be working in this space. And we couldn't be prouder to have Zach leading the charge, both for our clients and for the wider community.

So here's to Zach: MVP, architect, educator, tool builder, new dad, and all-around Teams Phone enthusiast. Congratulations on another well-deserved year of recognition!

---

_Want to follow Zach's work? Check out his blog at [zachb.uk](https://www.zachb.uk), his [YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@zachbennett), or connect with him on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zachjbennett/)._

projects.name: Zach is an MVP dontchya know.
projects.brief: Celebrate the achievements of our very own Microsoft MVP Zach Bennett.
projects.documentContent:
# Zach Bennett, Microsoft MVP: The Legend, The Laptop, The Low-Key Superhero

Some people collect stamps. Some people collect coffee mugs. Zach Bennett? Zach collects thank-you messages from strangers on the internet‚Äîand somehow turns them into real-world goodness. Which is a very long-winded way of saying: Zach is officially a **Microsoft MVP**, and we are extremely, unreasonably, enthusiastically proud.

If you‚Äôve ever wondered what an MVP does, the short version is: they‚Äôre the folks who make tech feel less like an impossible maze and more like a friendly, well-lit hallway with clear signs and snacks. (Okay, the snacks aren‚Äôt guaranteed, but Zach would absolutely bring snacks if you asked nicely.) Microsoft MVPs are recognized for sharing knowledge, helping others succeed, and generally being a force for good in the community‚Äîoften while running on a heroic combination of curiosity, caffeine, and ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that.‚Äù

And if you‚Äôve spent five minutes around Zach, you know ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that‚Äù is basically his personal brand.

He‚Äôs the person who can take a problem that looks like a tangled ball of holiday lights‚ÄîAPIs, configs, edge cases, one mysterious error message that only appears on Tuesdays‚Äîand calmly untie it while explaining what‚Äôs happening in plain English. The rest of us are standing there like, ‚ÄúIs it sorcery?‚Äù and Zach‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs just a missing semicolon‚Ä¶ plus three other things.‚Äù

But what makes this MVP recognition feel especially perfect is that Zach‚Äôs impact doesn‚Äôt stop at solving the thing in front of him. He shares the why, the how, and the ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how to avoid this next time,‚Äù so everyone around him gets better too. That‚Äôs the magic: not just fixing problems, but building confidence. The kind where someone who was afraid to touch a deployment pipeline is suddenly saying, ‚ÄúActually, I think I can handle it.‚Äù

Also, Zach does all this while staying genuinely kind. No gatekeeping. No ‚ÄúWell, _obviously_‚Ä¶‚Äù energy. Just steady, friendly expertise‚Äîand the occasional well-timed joke that lands exactly when you needed your shoulders to unclench.

So today we‚Äôre celebrating Zach: for the hours spent answering questions, writing up explanations, sharing insights, encouraging others, and showing up for the community again and again. The Microsoft MVP title is an awesome recognition, but anyone who‚Äôs worked with him already knows the real story: Zach has been doing MVP-level work for a long time. Now it just comes with a badge.

Drop a note, send a high-five, or unleash your favorite GIF in his general direction. Congratulations, Zach Bennett‚Äîour very own Microsoft MVP. May your builds be green, your logs be readable, and your coffee be strong.

+# Zach Bennett, Microsoft MVP: The Legend, The Laptop, The Low-Key Superhero
+
+Some people collect stamps. Some people collect coffee mugs. Zach Bennett? Zach collects thank-you messages from strangers on the internet‚Äîand somehow turns them into real-world goodness. Which is a very long-winded way of saying: Zach is officially a **Microsoft MVP**, and we are extremely, unreasonably, enthusiastically proud.
+
+If you‚Äôve ever wondered what an MVP does, the short version is: they‚Äôre the folks who make tech feel less like an impossible maze and more like a friendly, well-lit hallway with clear signs and snacks. (Okay, the snacks aren‚Äôt guaranteed, but Zach would absolutely bring snacks if you asked nicely.) Microsoft MVPs are recognized for sharing knowledge, helping others succeed, and generally being a force for good in the community‚Äîoften while running on a heroic combination of curiosity, caffeine, and ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that.‚Äù
+
+And if you‚Äôve spent five minutes around Zach, you know ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that‚Äù is basically his personal brand.
+
+He‚Äôs the person who can take a problem that looks like a tangled ball of holiday lights‚ÄîAPIs, configs, edge cases, one mysterious error message that only appears on Tuesdays‚Äîand calmly untie it while explaining what‚Äôs happening in plain English. The rest of us are standing there like, ‚ÄúIs it sorcery?‚Äù and Zach‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs just a missing semicolon‚Ä¶ plus three other things.‚Äù
+
+But what makes this MVP recognition feel especially perfect is that Zach‚Äôs impact doesn‚Äôt stop at solving the thing in front of him. He shares the why, the how, and the ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how to avoid this next time,‚Äù so everyone around him gets better too. That‚Äôs the magic: not just fixing problems, but building confidence. The kind where someone who was afraid to touch a deployment pipeline is suddenly saying, ‚ÄúActually, I think I can handle it.‚Äù
+
+Also, Zach does all this while staying genuinely kind. No gatekeeping. No ‚ÄúWell, *obviously*‚Ä¶‚Äù energy. Just steady, friendly expertise‚Äîand the occasional well-timed joke that lands exactly when you needed your shoulders to unclench.
+
+So today we‚Äôre celebrating Zach: for the hours spent answering questions, writing up explanations, sharing insights, encouraging others, and showing up for the community again and again. The Microsoft MVP title is an awesome recognition, but anyone who‚Äôs worked with him already knows the real story: Zach has been doing MVP-level work for a long time. Now it just comes with a badge.
+
+Drop a note, send a high-five, or unleash your favorite GIF in his general direction. Congratulations, Zach Bennett‚Äîour very own Microsoft MVP. May your builds be green, your logs be readable, and your coffee be strong.

# Zach Bennett, Microsoft MVP: The Legend, The Laptop, The Low-Key Superhero

Some people collect stamps. Some people collect coffee mugs. Zach Bennett? Zach collects thank-you messages from strangers on the internet‚Äîand somehow turns them into real-world goodness. Which is a very long-winded way of saying: Zach is officially a **Microsoft MVP**, and we are extremely, unreasonably, enthusiastically proud.

If you‚Äôve ever wondered what an MVP does, the short version is: they‚Äôre the folks who make tech feel less like an impossible maze and more like a friendly, well-lit hallway with clear signs and snacks. (Okay, the snacks aren‚Äôt guaranteed, but Zach would absolutely bring snacks if you asked nicely.) Microsoft MVPs are recognized for sharing knowledge, helping others succeed, and generally being a force for good in the community‚Äîoften while running on a heroic combination of curiosity, caffeine, and ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that.‚Äù

And if you‚Äôve spent five minutes around Zach, you know ‚ÄúSure, I can help with that‚Äù is basically his personal brand.

He‚Äôs the person who can take a problem that looks like a tangled ball of holiday lights‚ÄîAPIs, configs, edge cases, one mysterious error message that only appears on Tuesdays‚Äîand calmly untie it while explaining what‚Äôs happening in plain English. The rest of us are standing there like, ‚ÄúIs it sorcery?‚Äù and Zach‚Äôs like, ‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs just a missing semicolon‚Ä¶ plus three other things.‚Äù

But what makes this MVP recognition feel especially perfect is that Zach‚Äôs impact doesn‚Äôt stop at solving the thing in front of him. He shares the why, the how, and the ‚Äúhere‚Äôs how to avoid this next time,‚Äù so everyone around him gets better too. That‚Äôs the magic: not just fixing problems, but building confidence. The kind where someone who was afraid to touch a deployment pipeline is suddenly saying, ‚ÄúActually, I think I can handle it.‚Äù

Also, Zach does all this while staying genuinely kind. No gatekeeping. No ‚ÄúWell, *obviously*‚Ä¶‚Äù energy. Just steady, friendly expertise‚Äîand the occasional well-timed joke that lands exactly when you needed your shoulders to unclench.

So today we‚Äôre celebrating Zach: for the hours spent answering questions, writing up explanations, sharing insights, encouraging others, and showing up for the community again and again. The Microsoft MVP title is an awesome recognition, but anyone who‚Äôs worked with him already knows the real story: Zach has been doing MVP-level work for a long time. Now it just comes with a badge.

Drop a note, send a high-five, or unleash your favorite GIF in his general direction. Congratulations, Zach Bennett‚Äîour very own Microsoft MVP. May your builds be green, your logs be readable, and your coffee be strong.

projects.name: New features of Queues App in Teams
projects.brief: Talk about all the new features of Queues App in Teams
projects.styleHints: jokes all the time, not serious, causal, a bit sexy and spicy
projects.documentContent:
---
title: "Teams Queues App: Your Calls, But Make It Hot"
---

If your support line currently feels like a group chat where everyone‚Äôs typing ‚Äúwho‚Äôs got this?‚Äù while the customer slowly turns into a fossil‚Ä¶ hi. Microsoft Teams‚Äô **Queues app** is here to make call queues feel less like a haunted house and more like a well-lit kitchen where everyone knows where the snacks are.

At a high level, the Queues app is a **Teams-native** place for handling customer calls (powered by Teams Phone) without bouncing between tools like a caffeinated pinball. Agents get a clean workspace to answer and place calls; leads get the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm watching you, but lovingly‚Äù controls; admins get less ticket-driven chaos. Everybody wins. Nobody has to open _yet another_ tab. (Your browser can finally unclench.)

## Agents: the ‚ÄúI can handle this‚Äù era

First, the basics‚Äî**incoming calls**. The Queues app supports handling incoming calls whether they‚Äôre **PSTN or VoIP**. That means when the phone rings, you don‚Äôt have to go spelunking through Teams to find the right place to answer. It‚Äôs right there, like your favorite person at the party.

Then there‚Äôs the big relationship status upgrade: **Opt in / Opt out** of queues. You can join the queue when you‚Äôre ready to be perceived and dip out when you‚Äôre about to combust. And if your org uses **presence-based routing**, you‚Äôll only get calls when you‚Äôre _both_ opted in _and_ set to **Available**. Translation: no more getting queue calls while you‚Äôre ‚ÄúBusy‚Äù because you‚Äôre eating lunch with the intensity of a courtroom drama.

Need to call customers back, but don‚Äôt want to dox your personal number? The Queues app lets you **make outbound calls on behalf of the call queue or auto attendant** you‚Äôre assigned to‚Äîso the customer sees your org, not ‚ÄúMysterious Cell Number (Probably a Scam).‚Äù Professional. Branded. Slightly seductive.

And because we all love receipts: you can **view call history** (including missed calls with voicemail) and return calls with the queue-associated number. Flaky follow-up? Not in this economy.

## Leads: coaching without the ‚Äúmicromanage-y‚Äù aftertaste

Leads get the real fun toys‚Äîaka, the stuff that makes your team better _without_ turning into a spreadsheet goblin.

You can **monitor queues and people in real time**, opt agents in/out as needed, and (with the right policy + licensing) use the iconic quartet:

- **Monitor**: listen in quietly.
- **Whisper**: coach the agent without the caller hearing (the professional version of ‚Äúpssst, say the thing‚Äù).
- **Barge**: jump in and talk to both sides.
- **Takeover**: gently remove the agent from the call and handle it yourself.

It‚Äôs like being a call center ninja‚Ä¶ but with better UI.

## Analytics: because vibes are not a KPI

The Queues app includes **real-time stats**‚Äîthink calls waiting, average wait time, and other ‚Äúare we okay?‚Äù signals‚Äîplus **historical reporting** (typically up to the last ~27 days) and the ability to **export to Excel** for the folks who experience joy only when a pivot table snaps into place.

## The spicy new-new: Shared call history (rolling out)

The upcoming headline feature: **shared call history** for queue members‚Äîso the team can see missed, incoming, and outgoing call events in one shared view. It‚Äôs rolling out **January‚ÄìFebruary 2026**, and it‚Äôs **disabled by default**, meaning your admin has to enable it. (Yes, you still have to flirt with the Teams Admin Center a little.)

## Tiny but important fine print (aka: consent and licensing)

Queues app is available when users have **Teams Phone + Teams Premium**. Some lead features (like Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover) also depend on **voice applications policy** settings. Platform-wise, it‚Äôs primarily for **desktop/Mac/VDI**, and it‚Äôs also supported on **Teams phones (touch devices)**.

Bottom line: the Queues app takes call queues out of the ‚Äúeveryone panic separately‚Äù era and into the ‚Äúwe‚Äôre coordinated and slightly smug about it‚Äù era. Your customers get faster help. Your agents get calmer days. Your leads get actual levers to pull. And your team gets to keep everything inside Teams‚Äîwhere, frankly, we already live.

# New features of Queues App in Teams

**Type**: blog
**Word Count**: 500

## Brief

Write a ~500-word blog post highlighting _new / notable_ features and capabilities of the **Queues app in Microsoft Teams** (Teams Phone).

The post should:

- Explain what the Queues app is (Teams-native workspace for handling call queues / auto attendants).
- Highlight key agent + lead capabilities (see ‚ÄúFeature checklist‚Äù).
- Mention licensing/prereqs at a high level (Teams Phone + Teams Premium; some features require additional policy/admin enablement).
- Keep the tone: jokes throughout, casual, playful, _lightly_ spicy (PG-13), not serious.

Avoid:

- Inventing features not supported by sources.
- Confusing generic Teams Call Queues admin features with the **Queues app** experience.

## Style Hints

jokes all the time, not serious, causal, a bit sexy and spicy

## Feature checklist (grounded)

Agent/member flow:

- Handle incoming PSTN or VoIP calls in Teams.
- Opt in / opt out of queues; presence-based routing note (must be Available + opted in when enabled).
- Make outbound calls on behalf of assigned call queues / auto attendants (brand/privacy).
- View call history (personal history; voicemail-missed calls included) and call back.
- View real-time queue stats/analytics dashboards (waiting calls, average wait, longest wait, abandoned calls, etc; metrics depend on admin settings).

Lead/supervisor flow:

- Manage queue members (opt agents in/out) and monitor queues/auto attendants.
- Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover for coaching/escalation (requires Teams Premium + voice applications policy).
- Real-time + historical reporting (historical limited to ~27 days) with Excel export.

Admin/rollout notes:

- Licensing: Teams Phone + Teams Premium.
- Platform support: desktop/Mac/VDI; Teams phones (touch devices) supported; web not supported per Learn doc.
- **Shared call history** for queue members is rolling out Jan‚ÄìFeb 2026; disabled by default; admin enablement required; no tenant migration initially.

## Primary sources (for accuracy)

- Microsoft Support: Use the Queues app for Microsoft Teams
  https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/use-the-queues-app-for-microsoft-teams-370ad83e-c2c1-4a9f-8a59-16c98be102e9
- Microsoft Support: Monitor and assist team members in the Queues app (Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover)
  https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/monitor-and-assist-team-members-in-the-queues-app-in-microsoft-teams-677b6a8a-242e-40f1-9b47-90b7785959be
- Microsoft Teams Blog: Introducing the Queues app
  https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoftteamsblog/introducing-the-queues-app-enabling-customer-engagement-in-microsoft-teams/4095971
- Microsoft Teams Blog: Queues app now generally available
  https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoftteamsblog/queues-app-for-microsoft-teams-now-generally-available/4276837
- Microsoft Learn: Manage Queues app for Microsoft Teams
  https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-queues-app
- Microsoft 365 Message Center archive: Shared call history in Queues app (MC1188999)
  https://mc.merill.net/message/MC1188999

# New features of Queues App in Teams

**Type**: blog
**Word Count**: 500

## Brief

Write a ~500-word blog post highlighting _new / notable_ features and capabilities of the **Queues app in Microsoft Teams** (Teams Phone).

The post should:

### 1) Explain what the Queues app is (plain-English, 1 short paragraph)
- Describe it as a **Teams-native workspace** for handling **Teams Phone call queues and auto attendants**.
- Make it clear it‚Äôs for people doing day-to-day call handling (agents) and queue oversight (leads), **inside Teams**.
- Keep it concrete: ‚Äúa dedicated place in Teams to opt into a queue, take calls, place outbound calls on behalf of the queue, and see queue performance.‚Äù

### 2) Highlight key capabilities (use the checklist; pick the most exciting ones)
- Cover **both personas**:
  - **Agents/members**: opt in/out, take incoming calls (PSTN/VoIP), outbound calls on behalf of queue/AA, call history, real-time stats.
  - **Leads/supervisors**: real-time monitoring/oversight, coaching/escalation controls (Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover), reporting (real-time + historical) and Excel export.
- Don‚Äôt try to name every admin setting; focus on **what it enables in the app**.
- Include at least **one ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs new / noteworthy right now‚Äù** item (e.g., shared call history rollout).

### 3) Mention licensing/prereqs (1‚Äì2 sentences, not a licensing guide)
- Keep it high-level and non-scary, e.g.:
  - ‚ÄúQueues app is available with **Teams Phone + Teams Premium**.‚Äù
  - ‚ÄúSome supervisor features also depend on your admin enabling the right policies/settings.‚Äù
- Optional: a quick platform note if it fits naturally (desktop/Mac/VDI + Teams phones touch).

### 4) Tone requirements (how it should *feel* when reading)
- **Jokes throughout**: at least one joke or playful line every 2‚Äì3 paragraphs.
- **Casual voice**: contractions, conversational asides, light slang OK.
- **Lightly spicy (PG-13)**: flirty metaphors and ‚Äúspicy‚Äù phrasing are fine, but:
  - No explicit sexual content, no graphic language.
  - No harassment, no objectifying real people.
  - Keep it workplace-safe: think ‚Äúcheeky sitcom,‚Äù not ‚Äúlate-night cable.‚Äù
- **Not serious** doesn‚Äôt mean inaccurate: keep claims aligned to the sources.

Avoid:

- Inventing features not supported by sources.
- Confusing generic Teams Call Queues admin features with the **Queues app** experience.

## Style Hints

jokes all the time, not serious, causal, a bit sexy and spicy

## Feature checklist (grounded)

Agent/member flow:

- Handle incoming PSTN or VoIP calls in Teams.
- Opt in / opt out of queues; presence-based routing note (must be Available + opted in when enabled).
- Make outbound calls on behalf of assigned call queues / auto attendants (brand/privacy).
- View call history (personal history; voicemail-missed calls included) and call back.
- View real-time queue stats/analytics dashboards (waiting calls, average wait, longest wait, abandoned calls, etc; metrics depend on admin settings).

Lead/supervisor flow:

- Manage queue members (opt agents in/out) and monitor queues/auto attendants.
- Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover for coaching/escalation (requires Teams Premium + voice applications policy).
- Real-time + historical reporting (historical limited to ~27 days) with Excel export.

Admin/rollout notes:

- Licensing: Teams Phone + Teams Premium.
- Platform support: desktop/Mac/VDI; Teams phones (touch devices) supported; web not supported per Learn doc.
- **Shared call history** for queue members is rolling out Jan‚ÄìFeb 2026; disabled by default; admin enablement required; no tenant migration initially.

## Primary sources (for accuracy)

- Microsoft Support: Use the Queues app for Microsoft Teams
  https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/use-the-queues-app-for-microsoft-teams-370ad83e-c2c1-4a9f-8a59-16c98be102e9
- Microsoft Support: Monitor and assist team members in the Queues app (Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover)

- Microsoft Teams Blog: Queues app now generally available
  https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/microsoftteamsblog/queues-app-for-microsoft-teams-now-generally-available/4276837
- Microsoft Learn: Manage Queues app for Microsoft Teams
  https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoftteams/manage-queues-app

citations.excerpt: the Queues app is a **Teams-native** place for handling customer calls (powered by Teams Phone)
citations.context: Agents get a clean workspace to answer and place calls; leads get the 'I'm watching you, but lovingly' controls; admins get less ticket-driven chaos.

pointsCovered.point: For agents/members: opt in/out capability

citations.excerpt: **Opt in / Opt out** of queues. You can join the queue when you're ready to be perceived and dip out when you're about to combust.
citations.context: And if your org uses **presence-based routing**, you'll only get calls when you're _both_ opted in _and_ set to **Available**.

pointsCovered.point: For agents/members: take incoming calls (PSTN/VoIP)

citations.excerpt: **incoming calls**. The Queues app supports handling incoming calls whether they're **PSTN or VoIP**.
citations.context: That means when the phone rings, you don't have to go spelunking through Teams to find the right place to answer.

pointsCovered.point: For agents/members: outbound calls on behalf of queue/auto attendant

citations.excerpt: The Queues app lets you **make outbound calls on behalf of the call queue or auto attendant** you're assigned to
citations.context: so the customer sees your org, not 'Mysterious Cell Number (Probably a Scam).' Professional. Branded. Slightly seductive.

pointsCovered.point: For agents/members: call history and callback

citations.excerpt: you can **view call history** (including missed calls with voicemail) and return calls with the queue-associated number.
citations.context: And because we all love receipts: [this enables] Flaky follow-up? Not in this economy.

pointsCovered.point: For agents/members: real-time queue stats

citations.excerpt: The Queues app includes **real-time stats**‚Äîthink calls waiting, average wait time, and other 'are we okay?' signals
citations.context: plus **historical reporting** (typically up to the last ~27 days) and the ability to **export to Excel**

pointsCovered.point: For leads/supervisors: real-time monitoring and oversight

citations.excerpt: You can **monitor queues and people in real time**, opt agents in/out as needed
citations.context: and (with the right policy + licensing) use the iconic quartet: Monitor, Whisper, Barge, Takeover

pointsCovered.point: For leads/supervisors: coaching/escalation controls (Monitor/Whisper/Barge/Takeover)

citations.excerpt: **Monitor**: listen in quietly. **Whisper**: coach the agent without the caller hearing. **Barge**: jump in and talk to both sides. **Takeover**: gently remove the agent from the call and handle it yourself.
citations.context: It's like being a call center ninja‚Ä¶ but with better UI.

pointsCovered.point: For leads/supervisors: real-time and historical reporting with Excel export

citations.excerpt: **historical reporting** (typically up to the last ~27 days) and the ability to **export to Excel**
citations.context: The Queues app includes **real-time stats**‚Äîthink calls waiting, average wait time, and other 'are we okay?' signals

citations.excerpt: The upcoming headline feature: **shared call history** for queue members‚Ä¶ It's rolling out **January‚ÄìFebruary 2026**, and it's **disabled by default**
citations.context: meaning your admin has to enable it. (Yes, you still have to flirt with the Teams Admin Center a little.)

citations.context: Platform-wise, it's primarily for **desktop/Mac/VDI**, and it's also supported on **Teams phones (touch devices)**.
